elements.content: The synthesis and the crystal structure determination, using a synchrotron microdiffraction setup, of the interwoven analogue of the highly flexible iron(III) dicarboxylate MIL-88D structure are reported. Unlike its flexible counterpart, MIL-126, or FeIII 3O(H2O)2(OH)[(O2C)-C12H8-(CO2)]3·n(solv), exhibits a rigid structure with an accessible three dimensional (3D) pore system resulting in a Brunauer–Emmett–Teller (BET) surface area over 1700 m2·g–1. Moreover, a large amount of coordinatively unsaturated Fe sites of +2 and +3 oxidation states are accessible to NO and acetonitrile molecules as shown by infrared spectroscopy. MIL-126 might be thus used for the removal of aromatic N-heterocyclic compounds from fossil fuel streams, as shown here in the efficient capture of indole from model benzothiophene/indole mixtures in heptane/toluene.
elements.clean_text: The synthesis and the crystal structure determination, using a synchrotron microdiffraction setup, of the interwoven analogue of the highly flexible iron(III) dicarboxylate MIL-88D structure are reported. Unlike its flexible counterpart, MIL-126, or FeIII 3O(H2O)2(OH)[(O2C)-C12H8-(CO2)]3⋅n(solv), exhibits a rigid structure with an accessible three dimensional (3D) pore system resulting in a Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) surface area over 1700 m2⋅g-1. Moreover, a large amount of coordinatively unsaturated Fe sites of +2 and +3 oxidation states are accessible to NO and acetonitrile molecules as shown by infrared spectroscopy. MIL-126 might be thus used for the removal of aromatic N-heterocyclic compounds from fossil fuel streams, as shown here in the efficient capture of indole from model benzothiophene/indole mixtures in heptane/toluene.

elements.content: The search for new metal–organic frameworks (MOFs) is still a very active field. The association of inorganic moieties (isolated clusters or extended one dimensional (1D) or two dimensional (2D) subnetworks) and organic linkers leads to an increasing number of porous hybrid solids with various compositions (transition metals, main group elements, lanthanides, etc. associated with carboxylates, imidazolates, etc.) or structures, including new zeotype architectures. Their potential applications are focused not only on the storage/capture of strategic gases (H2, CO2, CH4) and separation of fluids but expand also to domains such as catalysis, thin films, inclusion, lithium battery materials, and biomedical applications. A special feature of a few MOFs is that they can be flexible with a drastic change in their cell volumes upon external stimuli (guests, pressure, temperature). This is the case for the MIL-88 and MIL-89 series of iron(III) or chromium(III) dicarboxylates (MIL stands for Material from Institut Lavoisier), which change in cell volume from 85 to 230%. As a consequence, once the guest molecules have been removed from the pores, the resulting MIL-88 dried forms are nonporous, and access to their Lewis acid sites becomes an issue. We report here the synthesis and single crystal structure determination using a microdiffraction setup of an interwoven form of the iron(III) 4,4′-biphenyldicarboxylate MIL-88D solid or Fe3O(H2O)2(OH)[(O2C)-C12H8-(CO2)]3·n(solv) (N,N′-dimethylformamide (DMF) and/or water) or MIL-126. The consequences of the interpenetration are analyzed here in terms of the changes in breathing capability, nitrogen sorption properties, and accessibility of the Lewis acid metal sites as observed in infrared spectroscopy experiments. Preliminary tests have been performed to probe the impact of the Lewis acid sites on the separation performance of the MIL-126 for a mixture of benzothiophene and indole aromatic molecules.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

The search for new metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) is still a very active field. The association of inorganic moieties (isolated clusters or extended one dimensional (1D) or two dimensional (2D) subnetworks) and organic linkers leads to an increasing number of porous hybrid solids with various compositions (transition metals, main group elements, lanthanides, etc. associated with carboxylates, imidazolates, etc.) or structures, including new zeotype architectures. Their potential applications are focused not only on the storage/capture of strategic gases (H2, CO2, CH4) and separation of fluids but expand also to domains such as catalysis, thin films, inclusion, lithium battery materials, and biomedical applications. A special feature of a few MOFs is that they can be flexible with a drastic change in their cell volumes upon external stimuli (guests, pressure, temperature). This is the case for the MIL-88 and MIL-89 series of iron(III) or chromium(III) dicarboxylates (MIL stands for Material from Institut Lavoisier), which change in cell volume from 85 to 230%. As a consequence, once the guest molecules have been removed from the pores, the resulting MIL-88 dried forms are nonporous, and access to their Lewis acid sites becomes an issue. We report here the synthesis and single crystal structure determination using a microdiffraction setup of an interwoven form of the iron(III) 4,4'-biphenyldicarboxylate MIL-88D solid or Fe3O(H2O)2(OH)[(O2C)-C12H8-(CO2)]3⋅n(solv) (N,N'-dimethylformamide (DMF) and/or water) or MIL-126. The consequences of the interpenetration are analyzed here in terms of the changes in breathing capability, nitrogen sorption properties, and accessibility of the Lewis acid metal sites as observed in infrared spectroscopy experiments. Preliminary tests have been performed to probe the impact of the Lewis acid sites on the separation performance of the MIL-126 for a mixture of benzothiophene and indole aromatic molecules.

elements.content: MIL-126 was prepared under solvothermal conditions using N,N′-dimethylformamide, iron(III) chloride, and 4,4′-biphenyldicarboxylic acid (4,4′-BPDC). Various synthesis parameters (time, temperature, ratios, concentration, etc.) were optimized, resulting in very small orange single crystals. Initial attempts to collect single crystal data using laboratory instruments or conventional synchrotron stations were unsuccessful due to the small size of MIL-126 crystals, while its large cell volume ruled out any structure solution from powder data. Its structure was thus solved from single crystal X-ray diffraction using the microdiffraction setup at ESRF (European Synchrotron Radiation Facility, Grenoble, France), previously used to determine the crystal structure of Al and Fe micrometer-sized MOFs. MIL-126 exhibits a tetragonal symmetry, a = 21.800(3) Å and c = 35.407(7) Å with the space group P43212 (no. 96), and is built up from oxo-centered trimers of iron(III) octahedra linked together via 4,4′-biphenyldicarboxylate linkers. As already observed in MIL-100 or MIL-88 structures, the Fe(III) ions bear four oxygen atoms from the carboxylates, one (μ3-O) oxygen atom and two types of terminal ligands, namely, water (2/3) and hydroxyl groups (1/3).
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Synthesis, Structure Solution, and Thermal Behavior

MIL-126 was prepared under solvothermal conditions using N,N'-dimethylformamide, iron(III) chloride, and 4,4'-biphenyldicarboxylic acid (4,4'-BPDC). Various synthesis parameters (time, temperature, ratios, concentration, etc.) were optimized, resulting in very small orange single crystals. Initial attempts to collect single crystal data using laboratory instruments or conventional synchrotron stations were unsuccessful due to the small size of MIL-126 crystals, while its large cell volume ruled out any structure solution from powder data. Its structure was thus solved from single crystal X-ray diffraction using the microdiffraction setup at ESRF (European Synchrotron Radiation Facility, Grenoble, France), previously used to determine the crystal structure of Al and Fe micrometer-sized MOFs. MIL-126 exhibits a tetragonal symmetry, a = 21.800(3) Å and c = 35.407(7) Å with the space group P43212 (no. 96), and is built up from oxo-centered trimers of iron(III) octahedra linked together via 4,4'-biphenyldicarboxylate linkers. As already observed in MIL-100 or MIL-88 structures, the Fe(III) ions bear four oxygen atoms from the carboxylates, one (μ3-O) oxygen atom and two types of terminal ligands, namely, water (2/3) and hydroxyl groups (1/3).

elements.content: It also immediately appears that the structure of MIL-126 is related to the MIL-88 structure type, which belongs to the acs net, and corresponds to two interwoven MIL-88D networks (Figure ). Analysis through the TOPOS software indeed confirms the presence of two interpenetrating acs nets of class IIa (Z = 2). The interpenetration leads to crossed channels, two along a and b with free apertures close to 4 × 7 Å, and an additional but corrugated larger channel system along the c axis with a free pore opening close to 10 × 11 Å. The building unit (Figure ) can be considered as two interwoven orthogonal hybrid bipyramidal cages with perpendicular equatorial planes, delimited by trimers of iron octahedra at the top of the vertices and by the organic biphenyl spacer at six of the nine possible edges.
elements.clean_text: It also immediately appears that the structure of MIL-126 is related to the MIL-88 structure type, which belongs to the acs net, and corresponds to two interwoven MIL-88D networks (Figure ). Analysis through the TOPOS software indeed confirms the presence of two interpenetrating acs nets of class IIa (Z = 2). The interpenetration leads to crossed channels, two along a and b with free apertures close to 4 × 7 Å, and an additional but corrugated larger channel system along the c axis with a free pore opening close to 10 × 11 Å. The building unit (Figure ) can be considered as two interwoven orthogonal hybrid bipyramidal cages with perpendicular equatorial planes, delimited by trimers of iron octahedra at the top of the vertices and by the organic biphenyl spacer at six of the nine possible edges.

elements.content: Projection of the crystal structure of MIL-126 (a) along [010]. To better evidence the relation with the MIL-88 topology, the structure has been decomposed into two interwoven elements, one in gray and the other in green, each of them corresponding to the MIL-88 topology. Hydrogen atoms have been removed for clarity.
elements.clean_text: 1  Projection of the crystal structure of MIL-126 (a) along [010]. To better evidence the relation with the MIL-88 topology, the structure has been decomposed into two interwoven elements, one in gray and the other in green, each of them corresponding to the MIL-88 topology. Hydrogen atoms have been removed for clarity.

elements.content: Organization of the two orthogonally interpenetrated trigonal bipyramidal building units (same code colors as in Figure ). Hydrogen atoms have been removed for clarity.
elements.clean_text: 2  Organization of the two orthogonally interpenetrated trigonal bipyramidal building units (same code colors as in Figure ). Hydrogen atoms have been removed for clarity.

elements.content: Note that whatever the synthesis conditions (especially concentration, temperature, and time), no evidence of the crystallization of the non-interwoven MIL-88D(Fe) solid was observed by X-ray diffraction, unlike for the chromium analogue MIL-88D(Cr). If MIL-88D(Fe) crystallizes at the initial stages of the reaction, there is not sufficient time for its particles to grow prior to its transformation (or dissolution-recrystallization) into the interwoven form MIL-126.
elements.clean_text: Note that whatever the synthesis conditions (especially concentration, temperature, and time), no evidence of the crystallization of the non-interwoven MIL-88D(Fe) solid was observed by X-ray diffraction, unlike for the chromium analogue MIL-88D(Cr). If MIL-88D(Fe) crystallizes at the initial stages of the reaction, there is not sufficient time for its particles to grow prior to its transformation (or dissolution-recrystallization) into the interwoven form MIL-126.

elements.content:
For a useful comparison with the highly breathing MIL-88D solid, the flexible character of MIL-126 was investigated through X-ray thermodiffractometry (Figure ).

First, MIL-126 is stable up to 553 K under air. Second, unlike for MIL-88D, only tiny changes in the Bragg peak positions were observed. Additional tests using a high resolution laboratory X-ray powder diffractometer were performed to determine the cell parameters of the as-synthesized and dried forms of MIL-126 (see Table ). The experimental cell volumes varied from 16785(1) Å3 for the wet DMF form down to 16526(1) Å3 for the dried solid, very close to the cell volume (16880(1) Å3) observed for the single crystal. This corresponds to a change in cell volume between the dried form and the as-synthesized solid close to 2%, versus 230% for MIL-88D. After outgassing the sample at 423 K overnight and exposure back to air, the cell volume is again close to 16800 Å3, which is, on the whole, identical to the one of the starting material. This observation confirms the absence of any breathing in MIL-126.
elements.clean_text:
For a useful comparison with the highly breathing MIL-88D solid, the flexible character of MIL-126 was investigated through X-ray thermodiffractometry (Figure ). 

First, MIL-126 is stable up to 553 K under air. Second, unlike for MIL-88D, only tiny changes in the Bragg peak positions were observed. Additional tests using a high resolution laboratory X-ray powder diffractometer were performed to determine the cell parameters of the as-synthesized and dried forms of MIL-126 (see Table ). The experimental cell volumes varied from 16785(1) Å3 for the wet DMF form down to 16526(1) Å3 for the dried solid, very close to the cell volume (16880(1) Å3) observed for the single crystal. This corresponds to a change in cell volume between the dried form and the as-synthesized solid close to 2%, versus 230% for MIL-88D. After outgassing the sample at 423 K overnight and exposure back to air, the cell volume is again close to 16800 Å3, which is, on the whole, identical to the one of the starting material. This observation confirms the absence of any breathing in MIL-126.

Cell Parameters of the Open and Contracted Forms of MIL-126(Fe) and MIL-88D(Cr) phase a (Å) c (Å) space group cell vol. (Å3) breathing amplitude (%) MIL126 crystal 21.8 35.4 P41212 16823 MIL126as (DMF) 21.7 35.6 P41212 16780 <1% MIL126 dry 21.5 35.8 P41212 16525 <2% MIL88 dry 10.2 27.6 P6̅2c 2490 MIL88D pyridine 20.5 22.1 P6̅2c 8200 230%

Amplitude = (V max – V min/V min)100.

The rigidity of MIL-126 is mainly due to the presence of adjacent phenyl rings from the two MIL-88D networks in the structure. Indeed, strong π stacking (see C–C distances between 3.4 and 3.8 Å) arises between the aromatic rings of the biphenyl linker belonging to adjacent hybrid secondary building units (SBUs) (); hydrogen bonds along the c axis between terminal water molecules coordinated to the iron centers (see O–O distances at 2.44 Å) are also present.
elements.clean_text: The rigidity of MIL-126 is mainly due to the presence of adjacent phenyl rings from the two MIL-88D networks in the structure. Indeed, strong π stacking (see C-C distances between 3.4 and 3.8 Å) arises between the aromatic rings of the biphenyl linker belonging to adjacent hybrid secondary building units (SBUs) (); hydrogen bonds along the c axis between terminal water molecules coordinated to the iron centers (see O-O distances at 2.44 Å) are also present.

elements.content: Both short contacts prevent the structure from any shrinkage. Moreover, elongation or contraction of both frameworks at the same time is simply geometrically forbidden, as their axes of elongation/contraction (x and y in Figure ) are perpendicular (the elongation of one framework along the bipyramid axis would require the contraction of the second framework).
elements.clean_text: Both short contacts prevent the structure from any shrinkage. Moreover, elongation or contraction of both frameworks at the same time is simply geometrically forbidden, as their axes of elongation/contraction (x and y in Figure ) are perpendicular (the elongation of one framework along the bipyramid axis would require the contraction of the second framework).

elements.content: As a result, while the MIL-88D solid does not exhibit any specific surface area for nitrogen at 77 K, its interwoven counterpart is a highly porous and rigid hybrid solid with a Brunauer–Emmett–Teller (BET) surface area close to 1750(50) m2·g–1 and a micropore volume of 0.71(1) cm3·g–1(Figure ). This surface area remains lower than the theoretical accessible surface area, which was estimated for the MIL-126 structure, considering all iron centers coordinated by water, to reach 2550 m2·g–1 (see the for the details of the calculation). This suggests the possibility to increase the porosity of the material by a more efficient removal of residual solvent and/or free acid molecules, which are still present within the pores.
elements.clean_text: As a result, while the MIL-88D solid does not exhibit any specific surface area for nitrogen at 77 K, its interwoven counterpart is a highly porous and rigid hybrid solid with a Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) surface area close to 1750(50) m2⋅g-1 and a micropore volume of 0.71(1) cm3⋅g-1(Figure ). This surface area remains lower than the theoretical accessible surface area, which was estimated for the MIL-126 structure, considering all iron centers coordinated by water, to reach 2550 m2⋅g-1 (see the  for the details of the calculation). This suggests the possibility to increase the porosity of the material by a more efficient removal of residual solvent and/or free acid molecules, which are still present within the pores.

elements.content: The presence of a significant permanent porosity in an interwoven MOF structure is common and has been observed previously many times. This is often used as a way to promote interactions with a gaseous adsorbate such as hydrogen, since interwoven structures exhibit a smaller pore size compared to their parent non-interpenetrated forms.
elements.clean_text: The presence of a significant permanent porosity in an interwoven MOF structure is common and has been observed previously many times. This is often used as a way to promote interactions with a gaseous adsorbate such as hydrogen, since interwoven structures exhibit a smaller pore size compared to their parent non-interpenetrated forms.

elements.content: Another advantage of interpenetration was shown through the rigidification of a copper-based MOF leading to a robust and highly porous framework. However, introducing interpenetration in a flexible solid that initially possesses no permanent porosity in order to get a highly porous rigid system is unexpected. This should drastically change the sorption properties, particularly for gases whereas no accessible porosity was observed so far for any of the MIL-88 solids, except in the presence of a large number and/or bulky functional groups such as for the diperfluoro or tetramethyl forms of MIL-88B(Fe).
elements.clean_text: Another advantage of interpenetration was shown through the rigidification of a copper-based MOF leading to a robust and highly porous framework. However, introducing interpenetration in a flexible solid that initially possesses no permanent porosity in order to get a highly porous rigid system is unexpected. This should drastically change the sorption properties, particularly for gases whereas no accessible porosity was observed so far for any of the MIL-88 solids, except in the presence of a large number and/or bulky functional groups such as for the diperfluoro or tetramethyl forms of MIL-88B(Fe).

elements.content: N2 sorption isotherm of MIL-126 (77 K, P 0 = 1 atm).
elements.clean_text: 4  N2 sorption isotherm of MIL-126 (77 K, P 0 = 1 atm).

elements.content: In situ characterization of MIL-126 has been achieved by infrared (IR) spectroscopy. This technique is very useful to study (i) the nature of the residual impurities such as water and biphenyl dicarboxylic acid and of the structural entities such as OH groups and (ii) the acidity and oxidation degree of the accessible metal sites after water removal.
elements.clean_text:
Infrared Spectroscopic Analysis

 In situ characterization of MIL-126 has been achieved by infrared (IR) spectroscopy. This technique is very useful to study (i) the nature of the residual impurities such as water and biphenyl dicarboxylic acid and of the structural entities such as OH groups and (ii) the acidity and oxidation degree of the accessible metal sites after water removal.

elements.content: Adsorbed water is well detected by the characteristic ν(H2O) and ν+δ(H2O) bands at about 3200 (broad) and 5220 cm–1, respectively. Figure shows that these bands disappear after outgassing the sample at 423 K (12 h). In such conditions, two bands persist at 1670 and 1740 cm–1 in the tail of one of the very strong carboxylate bands centered near 1600 cm–1 (Figure b). The 1670 cm–1 band intensity decreases by heating the sample under vacuum at higher temperature. This band is assigned to biphenyldicarboxylic acid (ν(CO) band) impurities, in agreement with results on other materials reporting that the carbonyl band frequency of the free acid is higher than that of the corresponding carboxylate group. As for the 1740 cm–1 band, it persists even after heating at 573 K, suggesting its assignment to an overtone or combination band of the solid. Another possibility is the formation of anhydride species characterized by a carbonyl stretching frequency higher than that of the corresponding acid.
elements.clean_text:
Impurities and Hydroxyl Groups

Adsorbed water is well detected by the characteristic ν(H2O) and ν+δ(H2O) bands at about 3200 (broad) and 5220 cm-1, respectively. Figure  shows that these bands disappear after outgassing the sample at 423 K (12 h). In such conditions, two bands persist at 1670 and 1740 cm-1 in the tail of one of the very strong carboxylate bands centered near 1600 cm-1 (Figure b). The 1670 cm-1 band intensity decreases by heating the sample under vacuum at higher temperature. This band is assigned to biphenyldicarboxylic acid (ν(CO) band) impurities, in agreement with results on other materials reporting that the carbonyl band frequency of the free acid is higher than that of the corresponding carboxylate group. As for the 1740 cm-1 band, it persists even after heating at 573 K, suggesting its assignment to an overtone or combination band of the solid. Another possibility is the formation of anhydride species characterized by a carbonyl stretching frequency higher than that of the corresponding acid.

elements.content: In the range above 2500 cm–1, in addition to the massif near 3050 cm–1 corresponding to the C–H aromatic groups, a weak ν(OH) band is observed at 3670 cm–1 (Figure A). This band is still present at higher temperatures and, thus, cannot be assigned to residual water species. Adsorption of CO at low temperature and CD3CN at room temperature shifts this signal toward lower wavenumbers with about 75 and 380 cm–1, respectively (). Such shifts reveal a weak Brönsted acid strength, slightly weaker than that reported for silica and for Al–OH and Cr–OH hydroxy groups on MIL-100(Al, Cr) when adsorbing CO (ν(OH) = 85–90 cm–1). This confirms the presence of Fe–OH groups, as expected from the chemical formula Fe3O(OH)[(O2C)-C12H8-(CO2)]3. Noteworthily, such hydroxyl groups have not been detected on MIL-100(Fe) due to the presence of halogenated impurities (fluorine), whereas the MIL-126(Fe) material should not contain such impurities (Cl/Fe < 0.05).
elements.clean_text: In the range above 2500 cm-1, in addition to the massif near 3050 cm-1 corresponding to the C-H aromatic groups, a weak ν(OH) band is observed at 3670 cm-1 (Figure A). This band is still present at higher temperatures and, thus, cannot be assigned to residual water species. Adsorption of CO at low temperature and CD3CN at room temperature shifts this signal toward lower wavenumbers with about 75 and 380 cm-1, respectively (). Such shifts reveal a weak Brönsted acid strength, slightly weaker than that reported for silica and for Al-OH and Cr-OH hydroxy groups on MIL-100(Al, Cr) when adsorbing CO (ν(OH) = 85-90 cm-1). This confirms the presence of Fe-OH groups, as expected from the chemical formula Fe3O(OH)[(O2C)-C12H8-(CO2)]3. Noteworthily, such hydroxyl groups have not been detected on MIL-100(Fe) due to the presence of halogenated impurities (fluorine), whereas the MIL-126(Fe) material should not contain such impurities (Cl/Fe < 0.05).

elements.content: Referring to spectroscopic studies of Fe-ZSM-5, this band is thus attributed to structural Fe3+–OH groups. Its intensity decreases by evacuation at 523 K, which can be related to a partial reduction of the Fe3+ sites, as shown below.
elements.clean_text: Referring to spectroscopic studies of Fe-ZSM-5, this band is thus attributed to structural Fe3+-OH groups. Its intensity decreases by evacuation at 523 K, which can be related to a partial reduction of the Fe3+ sites, as shown below.

elements.content: The CD3CN adsorption on MIL-126 activated at 423 K gives rise, in addition to the 2262 cm–1 band (physisorbed species), to a strong ν(CN) band at 2298 cm–1 characterizing coordinated CD3CN species and evidencing the presence of coordinatively unsaturated sites (cus) on the dehydrated material (Figure ). The same experiment performed on MIL-100(Fe) shows the presence of similar sites (ν(CN) at 2294 cm–1). Comparison of the spectra under similar experimental conditions (same activation and equilibrium pressure of the probe introduced) reveals a broader band in the case of MIL-100(Fe) (its full width at half-maximum (fwhm) equals 30 cm–1 instead of 20 cm–1 for MIL-126). The higher fwhm value reveals a higher heterogeneity of cus in MIL-100(Fe), which is confirmed by desorption experiments evidencing a high wavenumber ν(CN) component near 2307 cm–1. This is explained through the presence of halogenated counter-anions (fluorine) in MIL-100(Fe). It is well-known that the electron-withdrawing effect of fluorine modifies the Lewis acid strength of the neighboring cus. It can therefore be concluded that the absence of halogenated impurities in MIL-126(Fe) “homogenizes” the strength of the Lewis acid sites.
elements.clean_text:
Acidity and Oxidation Degree of the Accessible Metal Sites

The CD3CN adsorption on MIL-126 activated at 423 K gives rise, in addition to the 2262 cm-1 band (physisorbed species), to a strong ν(CN) band at 2298 cm-1 characterizing coordinated CD3CN species and evidencing the presence of coordinatively unsaturated sites (cus) on the dehydrated material (Figure ). The same experiment performed on MIL-100(Fe) shows the presence of similar sites (ν(CN) at 2294 cm-1). Comparison of the spectra under similar experimental conditions (same activation and equilibrium pressure of the probe introduced) reveals a broader band in the case of MIL-100(Fe) (its full width at half-maximum (fwhm) equals 30 cm-1 instead of 20 cm-1 for MIL-126). The higher fwhm value reveals a higher heterogeneity of cus in MIL-100(Fe), which is confirmed by desorption experiments evidencing a high wavenumber ν(CN) component near 2307 cm-1. This is explained through the presence of halogenated counter-anions (fluorine) in MIL-100(Fe). It is well-known that the electron-withdrawing effect of fluorine modifies the Lewis acid strength of the neighboring cus. It can therefore be concluded that the absence of halogenated impurities in MIL-126(Fe) "homogenizes" the strength of the Lewis acid sites.

elements.content: IR spectra of MIL-126(Fe) under room atmosphere (a), outgassed 12 h at 423 K (b) 3 h at 473, 523, and 573 K (c, d, and e, respectively). Insert: range of the ν(OH) bands, box A.
elements.clean_text: 5  IR spectra of MIL-126(Fe) under room atmosphere (a), outgassed 12 h at 423 K (b) 3 h at 473, 523, and 573 K (c, d, and e, respectively). Insert: range of the ν(OH) bands, box A.

elements.content: The integrated intensity, A, of the ν(CN) band centered at 2295 cm–1 has been measured for both solids and normalized to the same amount of Fe. The A MIL‑126(Fe)/A MIL‑100(Fe) ratio thus determined is higher than 1 (close to 4/3), which indicates that the MIL-126(Fe) sample contains a higher proportion of free Fe3+ cus, evidencing a higher degree of purity for this MIL-126(Fe) sample. The CD3CN adsorption on MIL-126 activated at higher temperature (523 K) leads to a weaker 2298 cm–1 band (about 20%) than that observed for the sample activated at 423 K (). This could be due either to the beginning of a collapse of the structure or to a partial reduction of the Fe3+ sites into Fe2+ ones, as reported for MIL-100(Fe). In order to confirm such a hypothesis, NO has been adsorbed at room temperature and at low temperature (∼150 K) on the MIL-126 activated at different temperatures (from 423 to 573 K).
elements.clean_text: The integrated intensity, A, of the ν(CN) band centered at 2295 cm-1 has been measured for both solids and normalized to the same amount of Fe. The A MIL-126(Fe)/A MIL-100(Fe) ratio thus determined is higher than 1 (close to 4/3), which indicates that the MIL-126(Fe) sample contains a higher proportion of free Fe3+ cus, evidencing a higher degree of purity for this MIL-126(Fe) sample. The CD3CN adsorption on MIL-126 activated at higher temperature (523 K) leads to a weaker 2298 cm-1 band (about 20%) than that observed for the sample activated at 423 K (). This could be due either to the beginning of a collapse of the structure or to a partial reduction of the Fe3+ sites into Fe2+ ones, as reported for MIL-100(Fe). In order to confirm such a hypothesis, NO has been adsorbed at room temperature and at low temperature (~150 K) on the MIL-126 activated at different temperatures (from 423 to 573 K).

elements.content: Adsorption of NO at room temperature on MIL-126 activated at high temperature reveals a band at 1815 cm–1 (Figure ). Its intensity strongly increases with the activation temperature (Figure b–d). Its position, close to that reported for NO interaction with Fe2+ cations on zeolites, is therefore assigned to nitrosyl species formed on Fe2+ cus created when the sample is activated under vacuum at temperatures higher than 423 K. Adsorption of an equilibrium amount of NO at lower temperature does not modify noticeably the intensity of the band at 1815 cm–1. By contrast, it leads to the appearance of a quite sharp new band at 1893 cm–1. Its wavenumber is close to that reported for NO interaction with the Fe3+ cation on Fe-silicalite and Fe2O3, and therefore, it is assigned to NO weakly interacting with Fe3+ cus. A band at intermediate wavenumbers is observed at 1850 cm–1 and corresponds to the formation of physisorbed species.
elements.clean_text: Adsorption of NO at room temperature on MIL-126 activated at high temperature reveals a band at 1815 cm-1 (Figure ). Its intensity strongly increases with the activation temperature (Figure b-d). Its position, close to that reported for NO interaction with Fe2+ cations on zeolites, is therefore assigned to nitrosyl species formed on Fe2+ cus created when the sample is activated under vacuum at temperatures higher than 423 K. Adsorption of an equilibrium amount of NO at lower temperature does not modify noticeably the intensity of the band at 1815 cm-1. By contrast, it leads to the appearance of a quite sharp new band at 1893 cm-1. Its wavenumber is close to that reported for NO interaction with the Fe3+ cation on Fe-silicalite and Fe2O3, and therefore, it is assigned to NO weakly interacting with Fe3+ cus. A band at intermediate wavenumbers is observed at 1850 cm-1 and corresponds to the formation of physisorbed species.

elements.content: IR spectra in the ν(CN) region of CD3CN adsorbed at room temperature on MIL-126 and MIL-100(Fe) activated at 423K (3 h); CD3CN has been introduced under an equilibrium pressure (7 Torrs (full line) followed by vacuum treatment at room temperature (dashed line)). Spectra are normalized to the same mass.
elements.clean_text: 6  IR spectra in the ν(CN) region of CD3CN adsorbed at room temperature on MIL-126 and MIL-100(Fe) activated at 423K (3 h); CD3CN has been introduced under an equilibrium pressure (7 Torrs (full line) followed by vacuum treatment at room temperature (dashed line)). Spectra are normalized to the same mass.

elements.content: One can thus conclude that after activation at 423 K, almost no Fe2+ sites are present, whereas after activation at 573 K, the number of accessible cus Fe3+ is lower. Therefore, infrared results suggest the creation of Fe2+ cus at the expense of the Fe3+–OH groups.
elements.clean_text: One can thus conclude that after activation at 423 K, almost no Fe2+ sites are present, whereas after activation at 573 K, the number of accessible cus Fe3+ is lower. Therefore, infrared results suggest the creation of Fe2+ cus at the expense of the Fe3+-OH groups.

elements.content: From a quantitative point of view, the number of NO/Fe2+ species assigned to the 1815 cm–1 band is estimated considering its molar absorption coefficient [34 cm·μmol–1]. This number is close to 300 μmol·g–1 for the sample activated at 523 K for 3 h, which corresponds to 12% of the theoretical amount of Fe sites. Such a fraction is similar to that reported for MIL-100(Fe) sample activated under similar conditions.
elements.clean_text: From a quantitative point of view, the number of NO/Fe2+ species assigned to the 1815 cm-1 band is estimated considering its molar absorption coefficient [34 cm⋅μmol-1]. This number is close to 300 μmol⋅g-1 for the sample activated at 523 K for 3 h, which corresponds to 12% of the theoretical amount of Fe sites. Such a fraction is similar to that reported for MIL-100(Fe) sample activated under similar conditions.

elements.content: Noteworthily, we have experienced that IR in situ characterization with probe molecules is difficult or nearly impossible for the MIL-88 series due to the closure of the pores when they are empty. This leads to a poor accessibility of the uncoordinated metal sites for the probe molecules due to diffusion problems in contrast with the interpenetrated form MIL-126, as shown by the very low intensity of the ν(CN) bands of both physisorbed and coordinated CD3CN species on MIL-88C (). In addition to the large accessible surface area, trimers of iron(III) octahedra present in MIL-126 can thus provide, as for the iron trimesate MIL-100(Fe), a large number of cus sites that might lead to a better affinity with respect to various adsorbates via a direct interaction with the Fe cus. As expected, our calculations predict an increase in the accessible surface area for the MIL-126 structure containing two unsaturated iron centers per trimer (2960 m2·g–1 vs 2550 m2·g–1) ().
elements.clean_text: Noteworthily, we have experienced that IR in situ characterization with probe molecules is difficult or nearly impossible for the MIL-88 series due to the closure of the pores when they are empty. This leads to a poor accessibility of the uncoordinated metal sites for the probe molecules due to diffusion problems in contrast with the interpenetrated form MIL-126, as shown by the very low intensity of the ν(CN) bands of both physisorbed and coordinated CD3CN species on MIL-88C (). In addition to the large accessible surface area, trimers of iron(III) octahedra present in MIL-126 can thus provide, as for the iron trimesate MIL-100(Fe), a large number of cus sites that might lead to a better affinity with respect to various adsorbates via a direct interaction with the Fe cus. As expected, our calculations predict an increase in the accessible surface area for the MIL-126 structure containing two unsaturated iron centers per trimer (2960 m2⋅g-1 vs 2550 m2⋅g-1) ().

elements.content: IR spectra of MIL-126 recorded after introduction of an equilibrium pressure of NO (10 Torrs) at room temperature (full line) or low temperature (150 K, dotted line). Spectra a–d: sample activated under secondary vacuum during 3 h at 423, 473, 523, and 573 K respectively.
elements.clean_text: 7  IR spectra of MIL-126 recorded after introduction of an equilibrium pressure of NO (10 Torrs) at room temperature (full line) or low temperature (150 K, dotted line). Spectra a-d: sample activated under secondary vacuum during 3 h at 423, 473, 523, and 573 K respectively.

elements.content: It was previously shown that MOFs bearing Lewis acid sites are attractive candidates for the purification of fuels from heterocyclic aromatics with preferential adsorption of S-containing derivatives in the presence of soft Lewis acid sites (Ni, Co, Mg, etc.) against selective adsorption of N-based aromatics on hard Lewis acid sites in MOFs such as MIL-100(Fe, Cr, Al, etc.). Thus, it was of interest to evaluate the use of MIL-126(Fe) for such an application.
elements.clean_text:
Adsorption of Heterocyclic Aromatics

It was previously shown that MOFs bearing Lewis acid sites are attractive candidates for the purification of fuels from heterocyclic aromatics with preferential adsorption of S-containing derivatives in the presence of soft Lewis acid sites (Ni, Co, Mg, etc.) against selective adsorption of N-based aromatics on hard Lewis acid sites in MOFs such as MIL-100(Fe, Cr, Al, etc.). Thus, it was of interest to evaluate the use of MIL-126(Fe) for such an application.

elements.content: In comparison with the parent MIL-88C material, the open structure of MIL-126 is a clear advantage. Indeed, experiments indicate that adsorption of large aromatic molecules on MIL-88C is insignificant. By contrast, in MIL-126, the presence of open metal sites can strongly enhance the selectivity of the material during the separation process. This was demonstrated in experiments on the selective uptake of N- or S-heterocyclic aromatics from hydrocarbon solvents, using a mixture of benzothiophene and indole in heptane/toluene in a 80/20 volumetric ratio as a model representative of fossil fuel streams. While the sulfur compounds can be mostly removed by catalytic hydrodesulphurization, catalytic hydrodenitrogenation is a more complex process. Moreover the N-heterocycles have an inhibitory effect on the hydrodesulphurization catalysts. Therefore, these compounds should be removed first (e.g. by selective adsorption).
elements.clean_text: In comparison with the parent MIL-88C material, the open structure of MIL-126 is a clear advantage. Indeed, experiments indicate that adsorption of large aromatic molecules on MIL-88C is insignificant. By contrast, in MIL-126, the presence of open metal sites can strongly enhance the selectivity of the material during the separation process. This was demonstrated in experiments on the selective uptake of N- or S-heterocyclic aromatics from hydrocarbon solvents, using a mixture of benzothiophene and indole in heptane/toluene in a 80/20 volumetric ratio as a model representative of fossil fuel streams. While the sulfur compounds can be mostly removed by catalytic hydrodesulphurization, catalytic hydrodenitrogenation is a more complex process. Moreover the N-heterocycles have an inhibitory effect on the hydrodesulphurization catalysts. Therefore, these compounds should be removed first (e.g. by selective adsorption).

elements.content: Adsorption isotherms for the competitive adsorption of indole and benzothiophene from heptane/toluene 80/20 on MIL-126: uptake (wt %) and separation factor α in function of concentration at equilibrium (weight ratio S/N of 10/7).
elements.clean_text: 8  Adsorption isotherms for the competitive adsorption of indole and benzothiophene from heptane/toluene 80/20 on MIL-126: uptake (wt %) and separation factor α in function of concentration at equilibrium (weight ratio S/N of 10/7).

elements.content: Figure shows that MIL-126 displays the desired preferential uptake of the N-heterocyclic aromatic compound indole, even though an S-heterocycle such as benzothiophene is present as well. The separation factor for indole vs benzothiophene is very high in diluted conditions, with a value of 6 at 0.1 M concentrations for both adsorbates. This remarkable selectivity must be due to a direct interaction between the open sites on Fe3+ clusters and the N-heterocycles, in which the hard Lewis acid Fe3+-sites prefer to bind indole, rather than softer bases such as the sulfur compound. Furthermore, the uptake of both compounds is a direct result of the interpenetration of the structure. From similar adsorption experiments performed on the non-interpenetrated analogue MIL-88C (), it is clear that the MIL-88 materials hardly display any uptake of the compounds. It seems that the relatively low concentrations of indole or benzothiophene are insufficient to open the structure of MIL-88C. Because of the interpenetration of MIL-126, the structure remains open, resulting in an uptake of the preferred compound indole, already at low concentrations.
elements.clean_text: Figure  shows that MIL-126 displays the desired preferential uptake of the N-heterocyclic aromatic compound indole, even though an S-heterocycle such as benzothiophene is present as well. The separation factor for indole vs benzothiophene is very high in diluted conditions, with a value of 6 at 0.1 M concentrations for both adsorbates. This remarkable selectivity must be due to a direct interaction between the open sites on Fe3+ clusters and the N-heterocycles, in which the hard Lewis acid Fe3+-sites prefer to bind indole, rather than softer bases such as the sulfur compound. Furthermore, the uptake of both compounds is a direct result of the interpenetration of the structure. From similar adsorption experiments performed on the non-interpenetrated analogue MIL-88C (), it is clear that the MIL-88 materials hardly display any uptake of the compounds. It seems that the relatively low concentrations of indole or benzothiophene are insufficient to open the structure of MIL-88C. Because of the interpenetration of MIL-126, the structure remains open, resulting in an uptake of the preferred compound indole, already at low concentrations.

elements.content: We report here the synthesis and characterization including its structure determination using a microdiffraction setup, of the iron(III) 4,4′-biphenyl dicarboxylate, denoted MIL-126, that is, the first example of an interwoven MIL-88 solid. We have indicated that interpenetration leads to a disappearance of the flexible character, resulting in a rigid highly porous solid. A large number of accessible reducible iron(III) metal sites has also been evidenced by in situ IR spectroscopy with probe molecules. Preliminary experiments have shown that MIL-126 is a promising candidate for the selective adsorption of heterocyclic aromatics from fuels. Considering the increasing number of highly flexible hybrid solids, such as those from the series of MIL-88 and MIL-53 structure type solids, this paves the way for the design of new highly porous rigid MOFs based on their interwoven networks, as candidates for gas or liquid phase separation governed by specific interactions with free metal centers.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusion

We report here the synthesis and characterization including its structure determination using a microdiffraction setup, of the iron(III) 4,4'-biphenyl dicarboxylate, denoted MIL-126, that is, the first example of an interwoven MIL-88 solid. We have indicated that interpenetration leads to a disappearance of the flexible character, resulting in a rigid highly porous solid. A large number of accessible reducible iron(III) metal sites has also been evidenced by in situ IR spectroscopy with probe molecules. Preliminary experiments have shown that MIL-126 is a promising candidate for the selective adsorption of heterocyclic aromatics from fuels. Considering the increasing number of highly flexible hybrid solids, such as those from the series of MIL-88 and MIL-53 structure type solids, this paves the way for the design of new highly porous rigid MOFs based on their interwoven networks, as candidates for gas or liquid phase separation governed by specific interactions with free metal centers.

elements.content: Synthesis and activation conditions, thermogravimetric analysis, infrared spectra, accessible theoretical surface area, and CIF file for MIL-126. This material is available free of charge via the Internet at http://pubs.acs.org.
elements.clean_text: Synthesis and activation conditions, thermogravimetric analysis, infrared spectra, accessible theoretical surface area, and CIF file for MIL-126. This material is available free of charge via the Internet at http://pubs.acs.org.

References

cln_elements.content:
The synthesis and the crystal structure determination, using a synchrotron microdiffraction setup, of the interwoven analogue of the highly flexible iron(III) dicarboxylate MIL-88D structure are reported. Unlike its flexible counterpart, MIL-126, or FeIII 3O(H2O)2(OH)[(O2C)-C12H8-(CO2)]3·n(solv), exhibits a rigid structure with an accessible three dimensional (3D) pore system resulting in a Brunauer–Emmett–Teller (BET) surface area over 1700 m2·g–1. Moreover, a large amount of coordinatively unsaturated Fe sites of +2 and +3 oxidation states are accessible to NO and acetonitrile molecules as shown by infrared spectroscopy. MIL-126 might be thus used for the removal of aromatic N-heterocyclic compounds from fossil fuel streams, as shown here in the efficient capture of indole from model benzothiophene/indole mixtures in heptane/toluene.

As a result, while the MIL-88D solid does not exhibit any specific surface area for nitrogen at 77 K, its interwoven counterpart is a highly porous and rigid hybrid solid with a Brunauer–Emmett–Teller (BET) surface area close to 1750(50) m2·g–1 and a micropore volume of 0.71(1) cm3·g–1(Figure ). This surface area remains lower than the theoretical accessible surface area, which was estimated for the MIL-126 structure, considering all iron centers coordinated by water, to reach 2550 m2·g–1 (see the for the details of the calculation). This suggests the possibility to increase the porosity of the material by a more efficient removal of residual solvent and/or free acid molecules, which are still present within the pores.
cln_elements.clean_text:
The synthesis and the crystal structure determination, using a synchrotron microdiffraction setup, of the interwoven analogue of the highly flexible iron(III) dicarboxylate MIL-88D structure are reported. Unlike its flexible counterpart, MIL-126, or FeIII 3O(H2O)2(OH)[(O2C)-C12H8-(CO2)]3⋅n(solv), exhibits a rigid structure with an accessible three dimensional (3D) pore system resulting in a Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) surface area over 1700 m2⋅g-1. Moreover, a large amount of coordinatively unsaturated Fe sites of +2 and +3 oxidation states are accessible to NO and acetonitrile molecules as shown by infrared spectroscopy. MIL-126 might be thus used for the removal of aromatic N-heterocyclic compounds from fossil fuel streams, as shown here in the efficient capture of indole from model benzothiophene/indole mixtures in heptane/toluene.

As a result, while the MIL-88D solid does not exhibit any specific surface area for nitrogen at 77 K, its interwoven counterpart is a highly porous and rigid hybrid solid with a Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) surface area close to 1750(50) m2⋅g-1 and a micropore volume of 0.71(1) cm3⋅g-1(Figure ). This surface area remains lower than the theoretical accessible surface area, which was estimated for the MIL-126 structure, considering all iron centers coordinated by water, to reach 2550 m2⋅g-1 (see the  for the details of the calculation). This suggests the possibility to increase the porosity of the material by a more efficient removal of residual solvent and/or free acid molecules, which are still present within the pores.

surface area.condition: considering all iron centers coordinated by water

cln_elements.content: Projection of the crystal structure of MIL-126 (a) along [010]. To better evidence the relation with the MIL-88 topology, the structure has been decomposed into two interwoven elements, one in gray and the other in green, each of them corresponding to the MIL-88 topology. Hydrogen atoms have been removed for clarity.

metadata.title:
How Interpenetration Ensures
Rigidity and Permanent
Porosity in a Highly Flexible Hybrid Solid
